title: Sense 3D scanner casing modification
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Do you own a 3D systems sense scanner, and find it very hard to use? You are not the only one. Using a Sense 3D scanner requires too many hands. You have to hold your laptop and the scanner at once, which makes fast and accurate 3D scanning a hard task to do. 
I've designed a custom casing with clips, so the scanner is way more compact and can be clipped to your laptop. Now you only have to hold your laptop while the 3D scanner is fixed. 3D scanning is a piece of cake now.
You can print the casing without supports and assemble it using 4 countersunk m3 x 8mm screws and two screws scavenged from the original Sense casing. An assembly tutorial video is available here:

Don't forget to tag @umakeprinting when you post your 3D prints from my 3D models on your Instagram or Twitter. :)

Do you like our designs?
Check out more from Umake: @ Twitter or click here to Follow | @ 3D Hubs | @ Youtube | @ Instagram

remixed_from.author: cevinius
remixed_from.title: MobBob V2 - Smart Phone Controlled Robot

description.text:
Wanting to make a MobBob, I found that my phone didn't fit in the original MobBob Phone holder. So I redesigned it to be able to hold a range of phones wide or narrow and with or without their protective cover. I kept the dimensions of the attachement to the rest of the robot.
All the parts can be easily printed without support. No need for screws or glue to assemble. First put the gear in place on the cover, clip the back to the cover and then slide the left and right braces in place while turning the gear. All thanks to Cevinius for creating such a cool little robot and app.

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes: I printed in relatively low resolution for speed and it works fine.

The little latches on the cover plate serve to maintain the gear in position (so that the side braces don't move once you've set it to hold your phone) and should click when adjusting. There is a very small gap between the latch and the rest of the plate to allow it to flex. Depending on your pritner and settings, you might need to re-separate it with a small blade to ensure it is only attached at the pin. Otherwise I have included a small chamfer anyway but the latches will be stiffer.

Upgrade for ToyREP 3D Printer - Fan mount to cool down hotend when printing PLA and bridges. Made for 40mm fan as all other fan mounts on ToyREP. Intended and designed for E3D v5 extruder clone.

• Printed fan duct - 1 pc
  • Wood screw 3x16-20 - 4 pcs
  • M3x16 screw- 2 pcs (already included in BoM of ToyREP - Fan Mount)

If you already have ToyREP assembled, you will have to remove two M3x16 bottom screws on extruder fan mount. 
Put two M3x16 screws through fan opening to the holes on sides of fan duct. Attach the duct to the extruder fan mount through bottom holes of 40mm fan that is already placed over the cold end of extruder.
Place 40mm fan over the duct opening and attach it by four 3x20 wood screws (3x16 if their head fit into mounting holes of your fan). Mind the orientation of the fan.
When these steps are done, the fan duct should be 2mm above the tip of nozzle. The slit should be heading to the nozzle.

Make the fan wires long enough to reach electronics. Attach the fan + and -  to empty extruder position on Ramps or other PWM controlled output and set it as a fan in firmware. Mind the polarity. Omit the signal and PWM wire - those are not required. Flash firmware and you are good to go.

It is really necessary to have this fan attached to PWM output so you can control it in slicing software. Otherwise if you use heatbed, this fan permanently turned ON will locally cool the print surface (that may cause warping) and prolong heating of heatbed and/or extruder.

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm nozzle, 0.25mm layer

Infill:

30%

description.text:
This is a work-in-progress; I'm still refining the holes and the offset near the bend. This is a parametric L-shaped bracket generator for MakeBlock which can generate parts of various sizes, similar to my MakeBlock Parametric Straight Bracket. All MakeBlock structural parts use M4 screws with the holes separated by an 8mm pitch, so I created this generator to generate L-shaped parts with a specified number of holes in the x, y, and z directions (as well as the part thickness). Most printers close inner holes up a bit, so a 2mm radius will create a part where the M4 screws "bite", and 2.4mm radius will create one where they're loose and need a nut. You can change all parameters in Customizer (be sure to scroll down to see them all) or by downloading the .scad file and opening it in OpenSCAD. The part prints on its side. By default the holes are in the shape of small octagons to allow most extrusion printers to print them accurately, but there is a selector to use circles or hexes. MakeBlock is a hobby robotics platform which spans from kids learning bots to advanced self-balancing bots, 3-d printers, robot arms, engravers, and more. If you create a new Thing with Customizer, please name it descriptively. v2: Replaced hack to get hex holes with actual calculation so it calculates correctly in Customizer. Also, can now set holes to any # of sides (include 0 for circle).
v3: Make corners angled and straight to improve layer adhesion while printing.
v4: Unroll loop to make 8-sided holes fast, clean up code.

A plotter attachment that will fit multiple pens, I use 2 clamps per spring.
3 versions:
-fine and springy
-fine and tough
-wide and tough
Gives pretty good results when plotting, but a step skipping seems to occur when changing pens, might be me bumping into the print bed. I use Inkscape with gcodetools to create the gcode for the K8200, just round all dimensions to 4 digits in gcodetools preferences.
Do a test run (low feedrate) to match your Z-offset and pen position.

Printer:

K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35

Notes: for the springs, the skin should be at least 3mm thick to keep the dovetail from snapping.
the thinnest spring is designed to be printed on a .35mm nozzle

Work in progress, testing out the limits of the K8200 step1 I built this to get more acquainted with 3d printing and CNC in general, a plotter seemed to be the first step in CNC. I might update this file to include a two sided dovetail clip, so you could use one spring at the top and one at the bottom to stabilise the pen. But a rubber band does the trick for me (for really basic plotting all you need is a rubber band). Next up I would like to try a mill mod such as

description.text:
NOTE: Development on Thingiverse has stopped. I will be continuing my development on Youmagine. https://www.youmagine.com/designs/parameterized-cup-holder The reason i am stopping development is Makerbot (the owner of thingiverse) has begun applying for patents for works done by the opensource printing community. This is theft of intellectual properties. I will leave this file up, but all future developments will be done elsewhere.
This cup holder is designed to work with Love-Sactional couches, but would work with many other couches. you can scale this to fit any cup or couch arm.

I bought a ThorFire PF01 on Amazon and the pocket clip kept catching on things and yanking it out of my pocket. I decided to fix this situation by designing a belt holster. Sure, it's a little Bat-Belt-ey, but it works and I use it a lot. 
I printed this in Inland black PETG - I love solid-color PET filaments. I then sanded it down just a bit to take off the most obvious ridges. If you're so inclined, you can put some elbow grease into sanding and make it as smooth as an injection-molded part; I usually just take it down until its smooth to the touch. 
I've included the .f3d archive so you can adjust it to your liking; I made it a bit shorter so I can push the flashlight out from the bottom when I want to.

Printer:

Custom Built CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes: I printed it standing up in black PETG on BuildTak. Bed temp 40C, nozzle temp 250C, @125mm/s. As you can see, I probably should have slowed it down a bit more, as there's maybe .1mm in z banding that sanding exposed. It might be filament variation, though, so that's a hard call.

I went to the hardware store and bought one of the big sanding sponges. A medium grit one. Then I picked up a 220 grit drywall sanding screen, and another 320 grit sponge. A few minutes with these in order leaves me with a smooth-to-the-touch finish. If I were more ambitious, at this point I could coat it with XTC and make it shiny smooth, or I could work through more sanding grits down to 1000 grit, but smooth-to-the-touch was my goal, not "factory finish".

title: Chess / checker board
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If there's ever a reason for an automated build platform, this is it. Here's a chessboard / checkerboard. (It's not up to me to decide what game you play!) It measures about 13" square. (That's 33cm for you folks with the better measurement system) In all, there are 401 pieces. 256 connectors
64 top pieces
49 bottom pieces
28 side pieces
4 corners I think it took me about 44 hours of printing time to make this, so settle in for the long haul. To the New Museum Challenge judges: I know this is 398 pieces over your limit. But in the spirit of the competition, I have made a derivative of your rules.

I'd recommend printing a top piece, bottom piece and connector first, then making sure the connector will snugly fit between the two, then scale the connectors accordingly. I made this for my printer, and they're all a little bit different. The top and bottom pieces should measure 1.5" square. I don't know if they'll get to you scaled the correct way.
There are additional files for less tedious prints, including a stack of 4 tops and bottoms, as well as a file for 20 connectors. It should all fit on a 4x4 printing platform.
I also suppose that you could sand it down after it's assembled, then brush it with acetone for a permanent bond and a shiny finish (if you make it with ABS), but I wasn't feeling up to it after spending so long on the process. Plus, I like the puzzle nature of it.

comments.text: If you alternate the color of the x's on the back you can use it for a tablero board, that's a game that uses a 7x7 board for play.
comments.author: Grimarr

comments.text: Agreed. You could also just take out a row on each side and reassemble it. :)
comments.author: Grimarr

comments.text: Yes, but my way you can have a chess / checker board plus a bonus tablero / whatever board on the back. The pattern on the back looks cool too. I'll post pictures when I'm done making it.
comments.author: edmo

comments.text: Thanks! I designed this to be printed on a cupcake, so the little pegs might not fit right on a more modern printer. You might want to check a couple of them and make sure they fit. I'll look forward to your pictures!
comments.author: Grimarr

comments.text: I'm making it on a Printrbot Simple, as for the connectors I found that printing them at 1.03 makes them about right.
comments.author: edmo

comments.text: It should be possible to significantly cut down the the part count and complexity by integrating the pins with the cross-pieces. Split each cross into two diagonals, print one of each colour, and press-fit them together. Opposite corners will have the same colour uprights, so when assembled into a grid you will have alternating coloured clusters of 4 uprights.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: That's true, but given the layered nature of the prints, the connectors could be sheared off where they connect. I've also thought that putting four of the bottom pieces together would also reduce the part count, but I liked the uniform size of all the parts.

Llave para el gas envasado de Argentina (Al menos el nordeste).  Funciona tanto en patas planas como las que tienen punta redondeada.
Un buen complemento para no "romperte los dedos" intentando apretar o soltar la llave de tres puntas domiciliarias. Además en la mayoría de los casos las patas se terminan rompiendo por utilizar fuerza bruta. 
Probado con envases de 10 y 15kg. No estoy seguro si para la versión de 45kg trae la misma llave.
Además una llave para el tapón de plástico, aunque posiblemente sea mejor idea imprimir una llave común. La idea original era combinarlas pero no se pudo.
Espero que ayude a que las comidas salgan a tiempo :)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30

Notes: PLA, 30% de infill (relleno), 3mm de shell thickness (bordes) y 4mm de superior e inferior. Si la vas a usar para trabajo diario creo que lo mejor es aumentar los bordes y no el relleno. Pero de por si es fuerte.
Advertencias Recuerda que estas trabajando con gas inflamable. Toma las medidas de seguridad necesarias y siempre comprueba que una vez apretado no pierde!.

A futuro

  • Suavizar los bordes de las llaves.

  • Preparar llaves para la apertura de la válvula. Suele venir demasiado apretada y no es posible abrirla manualmente.

Having several of the BX-25 for the Ruger 10-22 and having spent all my disposable income on building a 3D printer and having a desire to own some BX-25X2 clips it wasn't rocket science to figure out a solution. 
The Ruger magazine is full of slants and curves so it took 4 prints to get the fit I wanted.  This is a fairly good friction fit on my particular samples and it leans on the tighter side.   It's far easier to sand a little off if it's too tight than try to shim it up with something. 
The clip should only fit one way based on the way the magazine curves and the two different sizes of the slants on the corners. 
It's not a perfect fit, I wasn't shooting for perfect, just good enough to do its job.  
If you find it too tight a fit on your magazine then the magazine will leave some marks on the surfaces that are rubbing and a light sanding will fix that. 
You can use 1 or 2 clips per pair.  2 clips will give you a really solid pairing with more  friction if you find that your magazines are smaller than mine and keep them from moving around.  A single clip locks mine in pretty tight and saves a fraction of an ounce.  Each clip weighs a little over half an ounce at my settings with PLA. 
I thought about making it adjustable with an open space in the center and putting in a bolt that goes from side to side to squeeze the long sides together  but that would have increased the space between the two magazines more than I wanted and added a weak spot.  Feel free to remix it if you want something like that. 
My test pieces were printed in PLA but I'll print some 'for real' ones in black PETG which I think is more outdoor mud and wet friendly than PLA is.   And barring someone coming out with FDE or Coyote filament, black is more tacticool.

Printer:

MendelMax 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

30%

Notes: I printed these at 30% infill and 3 shells because I wanted the strength. At 60mm/s with my MendelMax 3 these take 54 minutes to print and cost roughly 0.50 cents to make with my PLA cost. In PETG they'll be a little more expensive. With those settings I honestly think after some twisting and pulling you'll break the magazines before you'll break the clip.

You may need to sand very lightly on some of the inner surfaces to get the degree of friction you're trying to achieve.   For my particular BX25's and my MendleMax 3 the off the plate fit is just about perfect.
Designed in Studio Max, took about an half an hour to knock out and another half hour of fine tuning after printing single and shallow versions to get the inside shape just right.

description.text: The new E3D hotends (Lite6, V6) have an integrated bowden coupler. This works great, but if the black collet gets pushed down it can cause the PTFE liner to come free, which can lead to the hotend jamming or failing. This is a small clip that goes around the collet, preventing it from pushing down and releasing its grip on the PTFE tubing. I was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:977392, but seeing as that is for the external bowden coupler I designed this one for the newer internal couplers.

description.text:
Saw an article on Internet about tempsensor to B6AC/IMAX chargers so I needed one.
http://www.filairsoft.com/forum/showthread.php?28692-Adding-Temperature-Sensor-to-you-IMAX-charger
Connected to my B6AC+ charger with an audio cable surplus from inside a stationary PC to it's CD-player just cut one pole and wire off ( se picture ).
Tested function by holding a soldering iron and let the charger take action and then measure the temp. Works like a charm.
I put a bit av plastic foam behind the sensor to have pressure on the sensor against the battery like a spring.
Enclosinig files so just enjoy modifying as you like.
/Ice

title: Wire Cage Cover And Bracket Assembly for Arduino Mega+Ramps on Makerfarm i3v 10" Printer

description.text:
Update: 6/17/16
Make sure you have enough ventilation for the electronics using this cover. I have stopped using this design until I find a better way to add some cooling to the electronics. I have been looking for a solution to cover my wires around the Arduino Mega + Ramps on the right side of my printer for awhile. After making the wood bracket for my LCD screen, I realized I could use the same idea on the side. I started out to just make the middle cover & then decided to do the whole side. You can cover just the middle section, Top & Middle or Middle & Bottom. I think there is enough ventilation with hex holes on the covers to not need a fan, but I added possible mount to the bottom bracket in the best place I could find for it out of the way of the wires. I just finished a 14 hour print with no extra fan & it did not have any problems. After I installed as always happens, I can see a couple of things I would change. I had forgot to connect the USB before putting these covers on & was not able to get it installed without taking that middle cover off. I added an optional cover to this set to give access to that, so you will not have that same problem. Putting the bolts on the inside hole covers is a bit of a challenge & I left the bottom one off. You will need to needle nose pliers to get those on. If I redo this design, I will probably change those inside connections to be a slot of some sort instead of bolts. When installing this, you of course want to unplug your machine. I used M3x14mm socket bolts on the cover & 1 M3x16mm socket bolt to connect the Middle Upper bracket to the frame. That bracket rests on the top of the electronics which pretty much holds everything in place vertically without bolting down. I would get your bolts & nuts out ahead of time, so you will know whether one or more is missing & possibly hiding in the electronics somewhere. When installing this, I had the best luck with starting at the bottom & working my way up. Also make sure that none of your wires are in the way of any of the parts being installed. I printed all these parts in PETG with 20% infill. There are 4 brackets to print & 3 covers.
Print Brackets: MF_i3v10_RightCover_TopBracket_Rev27.stl
MF_i3v10_RightCover_MiddleTopBracket_Rev27.stl (Print this 1st to check fit & Frame hole)
MF_i3v10_RightCover_MiddleBottomBracket_Rev27.stl
MF_i3v10_RightCover_BottomBracket_Rev27.stl (if you do not want Fan mount)
MF_i3v10_RightCover_BottomBracketWithFanMount_Rev27.stl (option if you want Fan mount) MF_i3v10_Right_TopCoverPlate_Rev27.stl (Print this cover 1st if you want to test fit)
MF_i3v10_Right_MiddleCoverPlate_Rev27.stl (If you Do Not want USB Acces Hole)
MF_i3v10_Right_MiddleCoverPlate_USB_Access_Rev27.stl (If you want USB Access Hole)
MF_i3v10_Right_BottomCoverPlate_Rev27.stl If you just want to use just the middle cover, you only need to print 3 parts.
MF_i3v10_RightCover_MiddleTopBracket_Rev27.stl
MF_i3v10_RightCover_MiddleBottomBracket_Rev27.stl MF_i3v10_Right_MiddleCoverPlate_Rev27.stl (If you Do Not want USB Acces Hole)
MF_i3v10_Right_MiddleCoverPlate_USB_Access_Rev27.stl (If you want USB Access Hole) The middle & bottom covers took the longest to print. The middle cover took over 4 hours & the bottom was almost 4 hours, but I used Archimedean Chords for Top/Bottom fill & 3d Honeycomb for fill pattern which I thought made it look nicer. I also included the openscad files of these which give you the ability to change it a little more. I used the Arduino Mega & 40mm fan from this for a reference in the assembly

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

Hey all, I've been working on OpenForge 2.0. I have a bunch of new features, and I'm hoping I can get people to test these out and give me some feedback. My goal here was to accomplish a few things.
  • Make OpenForge capable of doing multiple levels without having to use additional parts (frames)
  • Make OpenForge faster to lay out in game play.
  • Make OpenForge more of a pleasure to use.
  • Make OpenForge more modular and flexible for the needs of different GMs.
    • So, New features:
  • Openforge tiles now print with a very thin base. Many people don't want the tiles at full thickness, especially if they are not trying to match Dwarven Forge or Hirstarts tiles.
  • Because the tiles are thin, we can now print a variety of flue on bases. I've included my current favorite with this beta set, but really any base that can be designed at 6mm thick will work, so any creative ideas people have for new ways to connect tiles will work.
  • With the filament saver magnetic base, you can add 5mm buckyball style magnets. While these are not rigid enough of a connection to make large 2nd floors hold together, they greatly improve the "user interface" for the tiles. I personally fined the way the tiles pop together and align automatically a real pleasure. On a practical basis, these magnets add a few big benefits. Putting together a room is noticeably faster, because things naturally align themselves. It doesn't seem like it should matter, but it does. This also means that bumping the table, or people knocking into the dungeon with their hands tend to not do much damage to the dungeon.
  • The filament saver magnetic bases also have 6 little holes in them. These replace the need for a frame. Just snip paperclips (the big ones) in 2 places and you can make a rigid base for a room. I find this useful for being able to do both second floors and precreated rooms that are fast to lay out. Getting the paperclips in obiously takes more time, so this really should be reserved for work you do in prep for gaming, not at the table,
    • I've included a tips section to cover some of the things that I've discovered while working with this new tile style. Also as a note, adding magnets and glue clearly adds to the cost of the tiles. However, I've found that it's not significant when you compare the printed tile price to other tiles that are on sale. The magnets can be found for about $10 for 216 magnets. Each 2x2 tile requires 8, so this adds about $0.37 to the per tile cost. For me, the added usability is totally worth that. OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

Glue I use superglue to add the bases to the tiles. The square bits on the base are intended to be where you glue. That keeps the glue away from the magnets, which is important, because the magnet being able to turn is critical to this working well. It avoids having polarity issues. Now, lots of people hate using superglue. You open the bottle, and it goes bad if you leave it be. It can be super hard to control. Well, I use Loctitle ultragel control bottles, and they are wonderful. The way they work, the remaining glue doesn't go bad, and it's super easy to control. You press the two blue bars on the side, and that squeezes out a little glue. Also, I tend to use spring clamps for this. Loctite ultragel control Home depot spring clamps, get a bag for like $10

Hi, This is the 3D printed parts to build the front door for an Ultimaker 2.
The hinges are designed to let the user turn the door 270° around the axe.
It been inspired from this part : https://www.youmagine.com/designs/plexiglas-door-for-ultimaker-2 It improves the conditions for printing ABS and prevents from warping. We measured temperatures in the enclosure and we could record about 75-80°C (170°F) max when the heat-bed is about 100-110°C (210-230°F) You can found the top enclosure there : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1181123

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

75%

Notes: Don't forget to correctly oriented the part before printing it. All part have to be printed one time except the "2XHinge_plexiLock" and "2XHinge" that have to be printed 2 times. Printed with Colorfab XT. ABS with more infill might be OK too.

After Printing You can drill another time the M4 and M3 holes so that the assembly would be easier. You have to drill some hole in the polycarbonate sheet to avoid the two screws at the top front of the printer. (see the picture) Requirement Screws for hinge:
4X FHC M415or20mm ---> screws holding polycarbonate
2X CHC M335or40mm ---> hinge axe screws
3X CHC M3*20mm ---> replacement screws for the ultimaker
4X M4 nuts Screws for locker:
1X CHC M4*25mm
1X M4 nut (or nylstop nut) Poly-carbonate (4mm thick) :
1X 326*326mm Well... it's done ! Admire the success transformation ! ;)

comments.text: This looks good, but have you done a mod for the extended Ultimaker 2 printers? I think you could just modify the top and bottom pieces that attach to the side of the printer. Make each long enough to cover two of the screws, and just leave a gap between them. The overlapping feature would no longer be needed. The spacing between the screws is a little different from that on the Ultimaker 2, but it would seem to be pretty straightforward to make the new pieces. (By the way, as near as I can measure it on my printer, the spacing between the 4 screws on the side of the Ultimaker 2 Extended + is 4 13/16 inches or 122.25 mm in each case. Otherwise, everything else is identical.)

Check out my other frames at http://uberdesign.us These are the 3D printed parts for the Über Design Ü180. Print all parts flat and at 100% infill. Feedback welcome at the RCGroups thread at http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2543199 Print requirements:
100% infill for all parts
NYLON RECOMMENDED. ABS and PETG do not have sufficient elongation Parts:
4x - Ü180-V2-MOTORMOUNT
1x - Ü180-V2-MID
1x - Ü180-V2-CAMERAPLATE
4x - M3x10 (18mm-20mm button heads recommended. Socket heads will NOT fit)
4x - 10mm OD/8mm ID Carbon Fiber Tube, 116mm length
1x - 6mm OD/4mm ID Carbon Fiber Tube, 165mm length
2x - 6mm OD/4mm ID Carbon Fiber Tube, 79mm length
Assorted Zipties
Assorted nylon standoffs Support my work by buying parts here:
Glossy 10mm Tube, Prime Shipping: http://amzn.to/1ZJttw8
Matte 10mm Tube: http://amzn.to/1ZJtyjp
Glossy 6mm Tube: http://amzn.to/1Z0JzEE
Matte 6mm Tube: http://amzn.to/1ZJu1SC Assembly:
  • Insert 4 screws through bottom of MID
  • Slide 6mm tubes into MID
  • Slide 10mm tubes into MOTORMOUNTs
  • If gluing, apply glue before fully seating each rod. Ensure that rods going through MID are inserted into MOTORMOUNTs before compressing the frame to fully seat each rod.

The first freely available 15:1 thrust ratio frame!

  • Über easy: The first quad designed from the ground up with User Experience as a priority. Most easy to build quads compromise on performance. Most high performance quads compromise on user experience (advanced builds usually). This frame is nearly fastenerless with design features that allow you to assemble the quad easily using zip ties. Leave your allen wrench at home! Zip ties are light, intuitive to use, cheap, and strong. Hopefully (mechanical) repairs won't be so dreadful if swapping parts becomes simple.

  • Über cheap: This frame and its design will be openly available. CAD files are posted below so anyone can print or modify the parts to make their own frame! Total cost for me was only around $15 in parts. I may setup a store to sell pre-cut CF rods and SLS nylon or molded plastic parts so stay tuned!

  • Über light, Über fast: Weighing in at only 60g, it's one of the lightest 5" frames on the market. It's also currently the only 5" quad with potential for an 15:1 thrust to weight ratio with the Emax 2205 2600.

  • Über strong: CF tubes create a super rigid frame without all the extra weight of solid CF plates. Since it's a tube, you also have more isotropic strength compared to CF plates which can break more easily in some planes than others. Tubes also present a lower profile during fast forward flight compared to CF plates to decrease air resistance.

  • Über flexible: Swapping CF rods to create a 4" Ü150 or 6" Ü220 will be a breeze with zip ties. Just snip off the old ties, swap the rods, and zip tie the frame back up. Pair this with bullet connectors and you have a truly modular quad!

I timed the release of this guide to coincide with and commemorate the latest release of OpenSCAD[1]! The latest version (2011.12) was released today, so go out and get it now! I've marked this thing as a work in progress because it will need updating, though I won't update this thing, except minor/grammatical changes (any updates should be made in the form of a derivative, so anyone can do it!)
With OpenSCAD projects increasing in complexity every day, I think it's extremely important for those of us who use it to start thinking about a consistent style. The layout of the code is just as important as the technical accuracy and efficiency, because a good layout allows for readable, reusable, and maintainable code.
I would like to propose the following guidelines for style in OpenSCAD code. If you disagree, please speak up or create a derivative. I don't expect this to be the final word on the subject. My goal is to open up a dialog that will hopefully result in more maintainable OpenSCAD code.

Please follow these instructions as close as you can, but remember: "A Foolish Consistency is the Hobgoblin of Little Minds"[2][3]. In other words, if any of these rules cause your code to be less readable/maintainable you should not follow the rule in that particular circumstance. The goal is always readability and maintainability. At the very least, please pick a style and stick to it. White space Probably the most important factor for readable code is the right amount of spacing in the right places. In OpenSCAD, as in many other programming languages, white space (empty lines, spaces, and tabs) is ignored, which gives us the freedom to arrange the code in a readable, maintainable fashion.

In virtually all languages the suggestion (if not the rule, as in Python) is that whenever you begin some kind of code block (conditional, loop, module) your code should indent (with tabs or spaces) one level beyond the current indentation level. Ex: for(z = [-5, 5]) { // place the opening curly brace on the same line
Â Â Â Â translate([0, 0, z]) {
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â if(z < 0) {
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cube(size = 0.5, center = false);
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â }
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â else if(z > 0) {
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cube(size=0.25, center = false);
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â }
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â else {
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cube(size=0.35, center = false);
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â }
Â Â Â Â } // lines up with the block opener
} // For long code blocks use a reminder comment here (e.g. // for(z)) The placement of curly braces should following Compact Control Readability Style[4]. This makes the code fairly compact while making it easy to scan the left edge of the code for lined up control statements like if/else. Blocks should use open/close curly braces in all cases (even single-line blocks) to prevent mistakes. In OpenSCAD the indentation should always be done with tabs, not spaces, since the OpenSCAD editor indent shortcut uses tabs. It is, however appropriate (and encouraged) to use spaces to align constants and operators as in these examples: vector_of_vectors = [[0, 0, 0],
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â [1, 0, 1],
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â [0, 1, 0]]; polygon(
Â Â Â Â pointsÂ =Â [[0, 0],
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â [1, 0], // One tab, followed by spaces for alignment
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â [1, 1], // Ditto
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â [0, 1]],
Â Â Â Â pathsÂ Â =Â [[0, 1, 2, 3]] // Align the = operator
); Something to note here is that spacing for alignment will only work with a mono font, therefore it is recommended to choose a mono font in OpenSCAD's preferences. One unique rule should be made for OpenSCAD regarding indenting code blocks. Since transformations and assignments often come in groups (e.g. assign(...) scale(...) rotate(...) translate(...) {...}), one need not add indentation for each member of the group. It is much cleaner/readable in this case to think of the entire group as the block opener and line them up at the same indentation level. Ex.: assign(x = 5)
scale([1, 1, 0.5])
rotate([180, 0, 0])
translate([5, 5, 0])
if(y == 0) {
Â Â Â Â cube([1, 2, 3]);
} This should be done with assign, scale, rotate, translate, difference, union, and color but other block statements should only be used if they are the last item in the group. The first items in the group should always be "assign" statements if they exist.

Spaces are nice to provide some separation between elements in code, but it is important not to go overboard. Spaces after commas (,) makes it easy to read through list items, spaces around colons (:) makes it easier to read ranges, and spaces around operators (=, +, -, *, /, %, <, >, <=, >=, ==, !=, !, &&, ||) makes it easier to read statements in general. A solitary "!" should always have a space on both sides to make sure it is clearly visible. A "-" should always be surrounded by spaces except when it is acting as a unary operator (negating an expression). There is no need for spaces before or after parentheses (()) or brackets ([]), but a space before an opening curly brace ({) is helpful. Comments All files should begin with a comment block (/.../) describing the thing, followed by a Thingdoc[5] block that provides a more formal definition of the thing. A /.../ comment block before each module describing the input parameters is also useful. An example: /*
Â  Draws an awesome object!
Â 
Â  @param int width The width of the awesome object, defaults to 5
Â */
module awesome_object(width = 5) {
Â Â Â Â .
Â Â Â Â .
Â Â Â Â .
} If you are tempted to comment out code, first see if you can accomplish what you are attempting using conditional statements or modules and leaving all code uncommented. For example, this: // Uncomment the following line for an example usage!
//my_awesome_thing(10, 5); could be changed to this: module my_awesome_thing_demo(param1, param2) {
Â Â Â Â my_awesome_thing(param1, param2);
} For complex blocks of code, it can be helpful to include comments to describe the purpose of a particular line. If these comments are short they can be placed at the end of the line, following a // comment opener, otherwise they should be placed on one or more new lines above the referenced code (making sure to indent/align to the level of the referenced code before starting the comment). Line Length It's hard to provide a solid rule for line length since (as of this writing) OpenSCAD does not display line/column information. General guidelines can still be established, however. One should always try to avoid wrapped lines, because they make code much less readable. Of course, the width of the editor is different for everyone so just set your editor width to a reasonable size of the OpenSCAD window (around 50%) and see what wraps. You can fix these lines in the following ways:
  • Modularize code. If it makes sense in your situation, you can move code from the offending line into a module or function to shorten the line.
  • Split the line. Split the line into as many lines as needed where they will all fit on one line. Split after commas and operators and use a combination of tabs and spaces to line up with the previous line.
    • Naming Convention Variable naming in OpenSCAD should follow the underscore_naming convention to match the naming scheme used for OpenSCAD's built-in modules. In other words, variables should be all lower-case with underscores to separate words. Try and keep variable names short, unique, and meaningful. General Guidelines

Generally speaking, a module should not be over one page long. If you have a module this long, see if you can break out some of the code into separate modules to reduce the length of the module. You may be surprised to find that some of this code is reusable. Even if the code is used only once, taking this action can still improve readability. [1] http://www.openscad.org/
[2] http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/
[3] http://www.bartleby.com/100/420.47.html
[4] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indent_style#Compact_Control_Readability_style
[5] https://github.com/prusajr/ThingDoc/wiki/Syntax

title: Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Pachyrhinosaurs lakustai is a genus of ceratopsian, or horned dinosaur, from the Cretaceous Period that bore large bosses on their nose and eyes instead of the usual horn cores associated with Triceratops and its kin. There are three known species - P. pretorum, P. canadensis, and P. lakustai. They were fairly large animals that ranged from present-day northern Montana all the way into Alaska. Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai is notable for its frill ornamentation, which is more dramatic than in other species, and for having a space between its eye and nose bosses. It hails from the Wapiti formation in Alberta. While it was alive, the Western Interior Seaway was receding, leaving behind wetlands, peat swamps, river deltas, estuaries, and other wet environments in a subtropical climate. Like all ceratopsians, Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai had a battery of specialized teeth that allowed it to process tough vegetation such as cycads. This model was made in Blender and detailed in Mudbox. the polycount has been reduced for printing.

Ever since I got my 3D printer, I've always wanted to print this Eiffel Tower model: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22051 However, due to my nozzle size and total build volume, I could not slice/print some of the smaller features. So, I found the source SolidWorks file (https://grabcad.com/library/eiffel-tower) and slightly enlarged every small feature my slicer wasn't recognizing. I had to print this as big as possible for it to come out right on my printer (about 6in/152mm tall) using my 0.5mm nozzle. If you have a smaller nozzle size than 0.5mm, you may be able to print this even smaller. It was a very hard print, but it came out pretty well!

This is a puzzle cube that I helped design as a project in my Engineering class.  The project requires the team to draw the pieces as isometric views and multiviews.  What my team did was have me build it in tinkerCAD then print it out with my 3D printer to make sure everything fit together.  
My group decided it would be cool if we were to upload it here and share the design with others so they can print and assemble it.  
I will not post a picture of what the cube looks like in the preview so that people don't see the picture and solve it from that.  To remove spoilers, I will post a picture on the "I made this" tab.

Notes: Push download all files to make it easier. You can set it to be any size that you want. Without scaling, the whole cube is 3x3x3 cm. Resolution also isn't very important.

How it was Designed
  • My group talked about what we wanted the cube to be like
  • We drew out the Isometric views of all of the pieces.
  • I designed the pieces in tinkercad and printed them out
  • We built the cube out of wooden blocks based off of the Isometric views and the 3D printed puzzle.

The cable guide is designed to provide a 'clipping' point for the power and thermister cables that are attached to the hotbed.
Without the clip during bed movement the cable tends to bend at the solder points which over time will weaken and break.
The cable guide isolates the solder points from any movement.

Measure the diameter of the cable/cables that connect to your hot bed. Open the scad file and adjust the cableRadius variable to be half that of the cable diameter.
Generate the STL file and hit print. The Cable Guide prints with a small support surface between the two walls of the guide (it's the cross bar in the H shape that you will see at the start of the print). After printing you will need to cut the support surface out. If you want you can drill a hole through you print bed and use the M3 hole in the cable guide to bolt it to your bed. I didn't bother as the pressure fit of the guide was sufficient to hold it in place. I've attached STL files to suit a variety of cable diameters. Of of the STL's assume a 6 mm hotbed.

This is a small desktop vise which may be used for a wide variety of clamping and fixturing tasks. The design is based on the classic toolmaker's vise, which allows for a wide range of travel without the need for a long threaded rod. Despite its small size and plastic construction this vise is capable of producing surprisingly high clamping force, and is adequate for tasks such as holding work in a drill press. This design also maintains good parallelism between the vise jaws, even when clamping oddly-shaped objects. 
A 1/4-20 x 2" socket-head cap screw, as well as a matching washer and hex nut, are required in addition to one copy of each of the printed parts.

author: dvjcodec

title: Insertion plate (key) for European (EU) "SCHUKO" outlet with shuttered contacts

description.text:
Here is the insertion plate (key) for European (EU) "SCHUKO" outlet with shuttered contacts. Such sockets usually colored in red. It's needed to push lever in special hole to open contacts. So, in general it's impossible to plug generic cord to such outlets. Also, as the plate with special pin (which is longer than 2 contact pins) is intended to be glued to a plug, such plugs impossible to use in generic outlets.
This differentiation is used to separate electric lines. Let say, we have one line with red outlets for computers, which is backed up through one large UPS. And another line for generic appliances, such as lamps, teapots and refrigerators. So, using this special outlets it's impossible to accidentally plug electric teapot into the line under UPS. And vice-versa. BUT. In our office all sockets (red and non-red) are connected to same line. So, the need to have special keys to use some outlets have no sense. While using red outlets we did not glue keys to plugs, Key plates just permanently inserted into sockets. But from time to time these keys lost somehow. And at the end, almost half of outlets in our office are hard to use. So, I drew the replacement.
Key plate with short pin can be just inserted into socket and leave there.
With long pin (as on original one) it can be glued to plug.

description.text:
Continuing the madness... I was getting laughed at in my Design 101 class, so the only way I thought of to silence the other kids was to come out with my SuperShapes! After having done the previous SuperEllipse work, it was just a matter of time before the formulas came knocking at my door wanting to be implemented. This thing implements the SuperFormula (muwaaahhhaahaaahaaa)!! What the heck is that? Best thing is to take a look at the pretty pictures at this web site: http://paulbourke.net/geometry/supershape3d/ If you're really a math nutter, then take a look at the math as well. It's actually not that complicated. The complication here is just turning the formula into something that can be dealt with by OpenScad. In particular, making sure the thing turns out to be 2-manifold, so that you can actually generate .stl files and print the results, therein lies the rub. The supershape.scad files contains two rotines of interest:
RenderSuperShape2D() - This takes the definition of a single supershape, and renders the curve of that supershape in 2D, using wireframe. With this single routine, you can go to the wiki entry for Superfomula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superformula) and plug in the various numbers, and see pretty pictures. RenderSuperShape() - This takes two supershape definitions (one modulates the other), and renders real pretty pictures. You can look at the Paul Bourke site to get very interesting parameters to plug into that one. Another source of parameters might be POVRay files. That's enough for a Friday post I think. But wait, there's more... You also get the procedural texture mapping checkerboard pattern, thrown in for free. What is procedural texture mapping? Well, instead of using a bitmap to represent the different colors (or heights) on an object, you can just call a routine and ask it for the color at a particular position. No fus, no muss, no arrays to slow you down! At any rate, it's just a little hidden gem. This code is public domain. I figure having such a nice routine freely available might encourage people to make some very interesting shapes. Challenge: How the heck do you get OpenScad to display in wireframe, and with a fade on the other colors? UPDATE: 22102011
Added the tristar.stl file. This was an experiment in rendering the 2D shapes with faces, and not just wireframes, then using them with CSG operations. The result is of course a deadly weapon once rendered in hardened steel and sharpened.

1) Download the .scad files
2) Open up the test_supershape.scad file and play around with routines
3) See something you like, generate .stl
4) Print
5) Enjoy!

This is a small camera stabilizer in the style of the Tiffen Merlin. The body is made from pieces of hollow 8mm (.317") fiberglass epoxy tubing. A cheap universal joint from an RC car and two flanged f605zz bearings for the "gimbal".  Counterweights are simply 1/4 bolts holding some common steel washers.

I printed the parts in natural ABS at .2mm layer height and 20% infill. You may need to play around with the openscad files to get the holes sized correctly for your printer. The baseplate is sandwiched by two flanged F605ZZ bearings. The universal joint slides into the two bearings and is held in place with an M4 nut. The universal joint I used is HSP part number 106015 and can easily be found on ebay for about 6 dollars for a pair (you only need one). I used a hacksaw to cut off the tip of the "dog bone" to slide it into the handle. The upper fiberglass rod is about 125mm long, the lower is about 160mm. These can of course be customized to suit your needs/camera. I purchased my rods at Tap Plastics. They sell a 0.317"OD x 0.266"ID rod for about 4 dollars for a 32inch length. You will need to glue a nut to the bottom counterweight mount. I scuffed up the nut with sandpaper and glued it in place with Gorilla brand super glue. You will aslo need three 1/4-20 bolts each about 1/2" to 3/4" long (depends on the washers you use). If you search the interweb on merlin style stabilizers, you'll find lots of info. My favorite is wsclater's collection of works.. Some reading on stabilizers will also reveal that getting them balanced can be very very tricky. It took me a solid 2 hours of playing around with various combinations of washers and camera positioning to get it close. Also note that this is for SMALL cameras. Don't try to balance your expensive DSLR on this.

Edit : You may want to check the newer version : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1609490 This is an update of my first 100 size FPV micro quad (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1162507), following around 30 flights with previous version. I made the following modifications :
  • added a 15° angle on camera, Cool for FPV racing.
  • added stoppers below motors to prevent them for sliding and to protect motor wires.
  • added some plastic around the control board to make glueing easier.
    • The rest is unchanged : it uses the following parts :
  • Hubsan H107C control board : http://www.banggood.com/Hubsan-X4-H107C-RC-Quadcopter-Spare-Parts-Receiver-H107C-a43-p-87802.html
  • Hubsan H107C motors (8mm diameter x 20mm length) : http://www.banggood.com/2-X-8x20mm-Motor-For-Hubsan-X4-H107C-H107D-RC-Quadcopter-p-87683.html
  • JJRC 1000A propellers : http://www.banggood.com/JJRC-1000A-RC-Quadcopter-Part-Propellers-1000A06-p-928073.html
  • Eachine 700TVL 2.6mm Lens 1/3 CMOS 110 Degree FPV Mini Camera : http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-700TVL-2_6mm-Lens-1-3-CMOS-110-Degree-FPV-Mini-Camera-p-991027.html
  • Boscam TX5823 video transmitter : http://www.banggood.com/FPV-5_8G-200mW-Wireless-Audio-Video-Transmitter-Module-TX5823-p-84780.html
  • 500mAh 1S battery for motors : http://www.banggood.com/3_7V-500mAh-Battery-For-Hubsan-X4-H107-H107L-H107C-H107D-V252-JDX385-p-88012.html
  • 240mAh 1S battery for video (I use 2 batteries (one dedicated for video) to reduce interferences)
    • I use a Walkera Devo 7e transmitter running DEVIATION firmware. http://byoq.over-blog.com

author: Jherath

description.text:
Simple Case for the popular Transistor Tester GM328. Search for the board from your favourite Chinese Import site. Holds Tester PCB and Battery with snap off back cover and plug for the test lead socket on the side.
Designed for quick printing (2.5 hours for everything at 90mm/s on a .4mm nozzle)
.4mm nozzle can only just render the numbers on the front panel. Chose number free version for no numbers and use a sticker if you can't print that fine.

Printer:

Custom based on 3Drag

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20% recommended

Notes: Make sure your printer is well calibrated and printing to size...Everything fits if you print to spec but tolerances on the button/button hole and the PCB mounts will be tight if your printer is out of spec.

Assembly PCB mounts use M3 screws (the holes are 2.8mm so you should get just the right amount of bite on a machine thread M3 screw. If the button fits but activates the board when you screw the pcb mounts down then loosen the screw nearest the button slightly. I wanted more clearance on the release lever for the ZIF socket so I removed the socket from the board and put a standard DIL chip socket in-between the ZIF socket and the board. But the lever will work without this.
Drawn in Autodesk Fusion 360. Ask if you'd like design files to remix

Could you provide the source files for the transistor_tester_case.stl?

description.text:
Again, it's a latching deck box designed to fit a 60 card sleeved MTG deck. Unlike the previous version this isn't explicitly designed to be used as a library/graveyard holder during game play. I made the deck box smaller by getting rid of the dice storage as well as making the lid much shallower. In addition I put some slots in the lid to save on filament and added some lid decoration options:
-Plains
-Swamp
-Island
-Forest
-Mountain
-Magic M Choose the one you like, depending on printer you may have to glue it down. Print in one piece or in two pieces. I have not yet tested this print.

author: agdigital

description.text:
A 12mm wide replacement watch band for a women's watch. (or any narrow band) Printed with Taulman3D's PCTPE.
First, I printed each piece separately using the "vase" slicer setting which made a perfect 2 layer thick band with one layer thick loop ends for the pins and buckle.
Next, I used a sharp blade to cut a small gap for the buckle part. (I did not use the part W_cutout - it would need to be printed with support)
Finally, I heated a small screwdriver and melted the holes for the buckle while at the same time sealing the layers around the holes.

remixed_from.author: Lay3rWorks
remixed_from.title: HICTOP Prusa Extruder Fan Mount with Induction Probe

title: Hictop Prusa i3 Inductive Probe Fan Mount (18mm)

description.text:
UPDATE:  I've put up a new design (thinned the fan backplate, reduced the height, and changed the duct system).  I will update the older version as soon as I can to address the clearance issues - in the interim, you can always use a ziplock tie if your setup permits to help reduce some of the slop (i ran mine between the extruder/motor and mount).
Strider086 sparked my interest in creating an inductive probe for automagic bed leveling - so I decided to make an 18mm variant (all the orange-tipped, 8mm sensing probes I saw were 18mm, the blue-tipped ones are about 12.5mm).
I will likely update this design with a better performing duct.
I have yet to wire it up, but I plan on running this at 5v since I've read that it is possible to power them off the Z-axis endstop (rather than powering with 12v and dividing voltage with resistors).
I will upload pics when it is mounted and functional.

Printer:

Hictop Prusa i3 (extruded aluminum)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: I printed this part with PETG because I do not like to print with ABS and PLA might get a little droopy for a part within close proximity to the nozzle. I print PLA accurately and reliably at about 150mm/s, so PETG is REALLY slow to me - I am printing with PETG at 40mm/s (outer perimeter is 30mm/s and infil speed is 60mm/s). I hear the extruder click once and a while when doing infill at higher speeds but it doesn't seem to impact adhesion or strength that I can notice. Dropping infill speed to 45mm/s eliminates the intermittent messed up step (but also adds more print time when doing 100% infill parts like this one).
